1. Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder - F48.1
2. Major Depressive Disorder, Single Episode, Moderate - F32.1
3. Panic Disorder - F41.0
4. Post-traumatic Stress Disorder - F43.10
5. Generalized Anxiety Disorder - F41.1

vignette:
Lourdes Zayas, a 33-year-old Puerto Rican woman born in the United States, was brought to the emergency room (ER) after she became distraught and tried to swallow bleach.

The patient, who had no previous psychiatric history, had apparently been doing fine until the day before, when her fiancé was murdered in a drug-related incident in Puerto Rico. Her family reported that Ms. Zayas reacted initially with inordinate calm. Concerned, relatives discreetly followed her around in their small apartment for several hours. She did not speak but instead engaged in repetitive, unnecessary tasks such as folding and unfolding clothes.

That afternoon, standing at the washing machine, she had cried out, grabbed a bottle of bleach, and tried to drink from it. Her brother knocked it away. She fell to the ground, shaking, screaming, and crying. This episode lasted a few seconds, after which she “lay as if dead” for a few minutes. The family recalled no tonic-clonic movements, tongue biting, or loss of sphincter control. When the ambulance arrived, Ms. Zayas was crying softly, repeating the name of her fiancé, and was generally unresponsive to questions. After medical staff treated mild burns to her lips, she was triaged to the psychiatry department.

Over the next few hours, Ms. Zayas became more responsive. During a clinical interview done in Spanish, she reported being struck “numb” (insensible) by the news of her fiancé’s death and described a sense of being disconnected from her body, her emotions, and her surroundings. These symptoms were still present in the ER but diminished over several hours. She also described amnesia for what occurred from the moment when she cried out and her vision went “dark” (oscura), to when she “awoke” in the ER.

While being kept under observation for 24 hours, Ms. Zayas had two more episodes of sudden agitation, crying, and screaming, during which she attempted to scratch her face and to leave the room. Because she responded quickly to verbal intervention and reassuring physical contact, she was not given medications or placed in restraints, but was kept on one-to-one observation. Her laboratory test results were unremarkable, as were an electroencephalogram and a lumbar puncture.

On examination, she was crying softly, her mood was sad, and she said she did not remember making a suicide attempt. She was oriented to time, person, and place; had no psychotic symptoms; and denied current suicidal ideation.

Ms. Zayas was transferred to an inpatient psychiatric unit for evaluation. She initially had difficulty falling asleep and had sad, scary dreams about her fiancé. She denied recalling anything from the hours after she tried to swallow bleach. She made efforts to avoid thinking about her fiancé and was disturbed by intrusive recollections of their time together, but she never met DSM-5 criteria for acute stress disorder or major depressive disorder. Her symptoms had improved significantly after 1 week. She took no medications at the hospital and was discharged after 10 days with follow-up to outpatient care. She attended a single appointment 1 month later, at which point she and her family agreed that she was episodically sad about the death of her fiancé but essentially back to her normal self. At that point, she was lost to follow-up.
diagnosis: Other specified dissociative disorder (acute dissociative reactions to stressful events)
model_thoughts:
**Expert Diagnostic Process for Complex Case**

Okay, here's my thought process as I've worked through this complex clinical vignette. I'm taking the role of an expert psychiatrist, so I'm aiming for a Level 5 diagnostic reasoning here.

First, I zeroed in on the task: diagnose this patient using the DSM-5-TR. I'm focusing on the F-codes for psychiatric disorders and structuring my output exactly as required.

I jumped right into the data extraction, focusing on the patient's presentation: the traumatic trigger (murder of her fiancé), the acute presentation (suicide attempt, dissociation, conversion symptoms, and the clinical course).

Next, I zeroed in on the *ataque de nervios* - that was the pivotal clue here, given the patient's cultural background and the symptom constellation (screaming, falling, amnesia). That steered my thinking from the very beginning.

I then formed symptom clusters: Dissociation, Conversion, Emotional Distress, and the Trauma/Stressor. That broke the case down into manageable diagnostic categories.

I started evaluating specific DSM-5 diagnoses. I zeroed in on Dissociative Amnesia because of the significant memory gaps. Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder (Conversion Disorder) emerged because of the pseudo-seizure. Acute Stress Disorder was out per the vignette. Briefly Psychotic Disorder was a possible consideration, but the exam findings ruled it out. Adjustment Disorder became a strong contender, since ASD and MDD were excluded.

The cultural aspect guided me to the use of "Other Specified Dissociative Disorder" given *ataque*.

Ranking diagnoses was critical. I prioritized Unspecified Dissociative Disorder because of the *ataque* presentation. Conversion Disorder was my second consideration because of the seizure presentation. Following that, Dissociative Amnesia, Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder, and Adjustment Disorder were the remaining diagnoses.

Refining my F-codes was my next step. I self-corrected along the way to ensure I had the right ICD-10-CM codes.

Double-checking details, I confirmed that "Other Specified" was the most precise code to capture this specific presentation.

Finally, I got the list ready to go, prioritized with the best diagnostic fit at the top and formatted. I ran a final check to confirm that my clinical judgment was aligned with the formal diagnostic criteria.

All set.
model_diagnosis:
1. Other Specified Dissociative Disorder - ICD-10 F44.89
2. Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder (Conversion Disorder) - ICD-10 F44.5
3. Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder - ICD-10 F43.8
4. Dissociative Amnesia - ICD-10 F44.0
5. Adjustment Disorder with Mixed Anxiety and Depressed Mood - ICD-10 F43.23

vignette:
Michelle Adams, a 51-year-old former hairdresser, came to a psychiatric clinic at the urging of her primary care doctor. A note sent ahead revealed that she had been tearful and frustrated at her last medical appointment, and her doctor, who had been struggling to control the patient’s persistent back pain, felt that an evaluation by a psychiatrist might be helpful.

Greeting Ms. Adams in the waiting room, the psychiatrist was struck by both her appearance and her manner: here was a woman with shaggy silver hair and dark sunglasses, seated in a wheelchair, who offered a limp handshake and a plaintive sigh before asking the psychiatrist if he would mind pushing her wheelchair into his office. She was tired from a long commute, and, she explained, “Nobody on the street offered to help me out. Can you believe that?”

Once settled, Ms. Adams stated that she had been suffering from unbearable back pain for the previous 13 months. On the night “that changed everything,” she had locked herself out of her apartment and, while trying to climb in through a fire escape, had fallen and fractured her pelvis, coccyx, right elbow, and three ribs. Although she did not require surgery, she was bed-bound for 6 weeks and then underwent several months of physical therapy. Daily opioid medication had been only moderately helpful. She had seen “a dozen” doctors of various specialties and tried multiple treatments, including anesthetic injections and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation therapy, but her pain was unrelenting. Throughout this ordeal and for years previously, Ms. Adams smoked cannabis daily, explaining that a joint enjoyed in hourly puffs “softened” her pain and helped her to relax. She did not drink alcohol or use other illicit drugs.

Prior to the accident, Ms. Adams had worked at a neighborhood salon for more than 20 years. She was proud to have had a large number of devoted clients, and she relished the camaraderie with her colleagues, whom she referred to as “my real family.” She had been unable to return to work since her accident on account of the pain. “These doctors keep telling me I’m good to go back to work,” she said with visible anger, “but they don’t know what I’m going through.” Her voice broke. “They don’t believe me. They think I’m lying.”

She added that although friends had initially reached out after the accident, lately they had seemed less sympathetic. She let incoming telephone calls go to voice mail most of the time because she just did not feel up to socializing on account of the pain. In the previous month, she had stopped bathing daily and gotten slack about cleaning her apartment. Without the structure of work, she often found herself up until 5:00 a.m., and pain woke her several times before she finally got out of bed in the afternoon. As for her mood, she said, “I’m so depressed it’s ridiculous.” She often felt hopeless of any possibility of living without pain but denied ever thinking of suicide. She explained that her Catholic faith prevented her from considering taking her own life.

Ms. Adams had never seen a psychiatrist before and did not recall ever having felt depressed prior to her accident, although she described a “hot temper” as a family trait. She spoke of only one meaningful romantic relationship, many years previously, with a woman who was emotionally abusive. When asked about any legal difficulties, she revealed several arrests for theft in her 20s. She was “in the wrong place at the wrong time,” she said, and was never convicted of a crime.
diagnosis:
1. Somatic symptom disorder, with predominant pain, persistent, moderate to severe
2. Cannabis use disorder
3. Major depressive disorder, single episode, chronic
model_thoughts:
**Expert Diagnostic Thoughts on a Challenging Case**

Okay, here's what I'm thinking, working through this complex clinical picture: First, I zero in on the core of the problem: persistent pain way beyond what you'd expect after the initial injury. The patient, Michelle Adams, seems trapped in this cycle, and it's taking a huge toll. I immediately recognize Somatic Symptom Disorder with pain as the primary diagnosis. This diagnosis perfectly explains her suffering and her interaction with the medical system.

The depression is another major piece of the puzzle. It's clearly linked to the chronic pain and loss of function, making Major Depressive Disorder, single episode, the appropriate diagnosis. Her daily cannabis use is also a concern – it's likely a form of self-medication, so Cannabis Use Disorder, moderate seems appropriate.

Now comes the trickier part: personality. Her history, particularly the arrests, temper, and unstable relationships, definitely point to personality pathology. The "hot temper" and instability suggest Borderline Personality Disorder, although her behavior also hints at Antisocial traits. I'm leaning heavily towards Borderline since the vignette emphasizes her emotional volatility, and it's a very common comorbid finding with Somatic Symptom Disorder.

Finally, the daily opioid use is a big red flag. Given the "doctor shopping" behavior, and the fact that the medication is only "moderately helpful," Opioid Use Disorder is a high probability, so I'll include it.

So, here's my list, which reflects these clinical assessments: 1. Somatic Symptom Disorder (F45.1), 2. Major Depressive Disorder, single episode, severe (F32.2), 3. Cannabis Use Disorder, moderate (F12.20), 4. Borderline Personality Disorder (F60.3), and 5. Opioid Use Disorder (F11.20). This reflects the core problem (SSD), the reaction (MDD), the self-medication (Cannabis), the personality that drives the maladaptive patterns (BPD) and a crucial safety diagnosis: Opioid Use Disorder. The history of arrests is a clinical finding but does not outweigh the BPD.
model_diagnosis:
1. Somatic symptom disorder - F45.1
2. Major depressive disorder, single episode, severe - F32.2
3. Cannabis use disorder, moderate - F12.20
4. Borderline personality disorder - F60.3
5. Opioid use disorder, moderate - F11.20

vignette:
Norma Balaban, a 37-year-old married woman who worked as an administrative assistant to a university dean, was referred by her primary care physician for evaluation of depression and multiple somatic symptoms. She had been generally healthy, other than binge eating and obesity, until a year earlier and had undergone gastric bypass surgery 6 years earlier.

As she entered the consulting room, Ms. Balaban handed the psychiatrist a three-page summary of her physical concerns. Nocturnal leg spasms and daytime leg aches had been her initial concerns. She then developed sleep difficulties that led to “brain fog” and head heaviness. She had intermittent cold sensations in her extremities, face, ears, eyes, and nasal passages. Pulsating sensations in her eyes were, she thought, more pronounced after a poor night’s sleep. In recent months, she had developed difficulty urinating, menstrual irregularity, and multiple muscle complaints, including right gluteal pain with a burning sensation into her right thigh. She also had neck stiffness with accompanying thoracic back spasms.

Ms. Balaban’s primary care physician had evaluated the initial symptoms and then referred her to a rheumatologist and a neurologist. The rheumatologist diagnosed mechanical back pain without evidence of inflammatory arthritis. She had also diagnosed possible migraines with peripheral neuropathic and ocular symptoms. The neurologist noted that Ms. Balaban was also being evaluated by a neurologist and a neuro-ophthalmologist at a nearby medical center. The other neurologist concluded her evaluation with a provisional diagnosis of “atypical migraine variant,” noting that “the patient seemed to also have a significant degree of depression, which might be aggravating the symptoms or even be an underlying precipitating factor.” A review of tests done at the two medical centers indicated that Ms. Balaban had received the following essentially normal tests: two electroencephalograms, an electromyogram, three brain and three spinal magnetic resonance images, two lumbar puncture studies, and serial laboratory exams. Psychiatric consultation had been recommended, but the patient declined until repeatedly urged by her primary care physician.

Ms. Balaban initially spoke to the psychiatrist primarily about her physical complaints. She was very frustrated that despite having seen several specialists, she had received no clear diagnosis, and she was still very concerned about her symptoms. She had started taking fluoxetine and gabapentin, prescribed by her primary care physician, and experienced partial improvement in her mood and some of her pains. She found it difficult to concentrate and complete her work and was spending a lot of time on the internet researching her symptoms. For the past several months, she had kept a spreadsheet that tried to link her symptoms to her blood pressure and pulse.

She also felt bad about not spending enough time with her children or husband, but just did not have the energy. She acknowledged bouts of depressed mood over the prior year with some anhedonia and occasional thoughts of suicide (she had considered crashing her car), but no anorexia or guilt. She described having experienced premenstrual depressive symptoms for about a year.

Ms. Balaban had been treated for postpartum depression 6 years earlier after the birth of her second child. Family history was significant for cancer, depression, and hypertension.

Ms. Balaban lived with her husband and their daughters, ages 10 and 6 years. Her husband was being treated for depression. The patient had graduated from college and was the longtime administrative assistant to a dean at the local university. She grew up in a small town in a rural area. She reported a happy childhood and denied any experiences of physical or sexual abuse. There was no history of a substance use disorder.

On mental status examination, the patient was alert, casually but neatly dressed, cooperative, and not at all defensive. Her mood and affect were depressed, and she demonstrated psychomotor retardation. There were no abnormalities of thought process or content, no abnormalities of perception, and no evident cognitive dysfunction.
diagnosis: Somatic symptom disorder
model_thoughts:
**A Psychiatrist's Thought Process: Diagnosing Ms. Balaban**

Alright, let's break this down. First, I need to understand the constraints: this is about a diagnosis, using the DSM-5-TR, and a level 5 performance requires a deep understanding of the data. I'm looking at Ms. Balaban, a 37-year-old woman with a complex presentation. My initial impression is that there are *many* overlapping symptoms here.

1. **The Core Complaint: Somatic Symptoms.** She's got leg spasms, brain fog, head heaviness... the list goes on.  The fact that she's had such extensive testing, with negative results, is a *major* red flag for Somatic Symptom Disorder.  The excessive health preoccupation, the time spent researching, the spreadsheets... that seals it. We're talking F45.1.  This feels like the driving force behind everything else.

2. **The Mood Picture: Depression.**  The depressed mood, anhedonia, suicidal ideation... it's all there.  With a history of postpartum depression, it's pretty clear this is a recurrent major depressive episode (F33.1 or F33.2; I'm leaning toward F33.1 as she's not hospitalized, but the suicidal ideation is concerning).

3. **The Female Factor: Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder.**  The premenstrual depressive symptoms are too obvious to ignore. That’s F32.81.

4. **The Weight History: Binge Eating Disorder.**  The history of "binge eating and obesity" is concerning, even if it has changed. I suspect this will be significant for her health history. Let's make sure that's included, potentially in remission, as F50.81.

5. **The Link to the Body: Psychological Factors Affecting Other Medical Conditions.** The fact that she was diagnosed with an "atypical migraine" *and* depression is notable.  The interplay between the physical symptoms, the emotional distress, and the impact on daily life is significant.  The F54 code feels right.

I considered Illness Anxiety Disorder, but she *has* actual, if unexplained, somatic symptoms.  Generalized Anxiety Disorder isn’t quite the right fit because the worry is so strongly tied to the physical. While insomnia is possible, F54 better describes the interplay.  And while obsessive-compulsive traits might be present, there isn't enough to warrant a diagnosis.

So, here's my final list, ordered by importance: 1) Somatic Symptom Disorder - F45.1, 2) Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent, Moderate - F33.1, 3) Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder - F32.81, 4) Binge Eating Disorder - F50.81, and 5) Psychological Factors Affecting Other Medical Conditions - F54.
model_diagnosis:
1. Somatic Symptom Disorder - F45.1
2. Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent, Moderate - F33.1
3. Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder - F32.81
4. Binge Eating Disorder - F50.81
5. Psychological Factors Affecting Other Medical Conditions - F54

vignette:
Oscar Capek, a 43-year-old man, was brought by his wife to an emergency room (ER) for what he described as a relapse of his chronic Lyme disease. He explained that he had been fatigued for a month and bedridden for a week. Then, saying he was too tired and confused to give much information, he asked the ER team to call his psychiatrist.

The psychiatrist reported that he had treated Mr. Capek for more than two decades. He first saw Mr. Capek for a panic attack. It resolved with surprisingly small doses of clonazepam. After that, however, Mr. Capek continued to see him for help coping with his chronic illness. Initially a graduate student pursuing a master’s degree in accounting, Mr. Capek dropped out of school over worries that the demands of his studies would exacerbate his disease. Since that time, his wife, a registered nurse, had been his primary support. He supplemented their income with small accounting jobs but limited these lest the stress affect his health.

Mr. Capek usually felt physically and emotionally well. He deemed his occasional fatigue, anxiety, and concentration difficulties “controllable” and did not require treatment. Mr. Capek was typically averse to psychotropic medications and took a homeopathic approach to his disease, including exercise and proper nutrition. When his panic symptoms would reemerge, he used small doses (e.g., one-quarter of a 0.5-mg lorazepam pill). His psychiatric sessions were commonly concerned about his underlying disease; he often brought articles on chronic Lyme disease for discussion and was active in a local Lyme disease support group.

Mr. Capek’s symptoms would occasionally worsen. However, these worsenings occurred less than yearly, and these “exacerbations” usually related to some apparent stress. The worst episode had been 1 year earlier, when his wife briefly left him following his revelation of an affair. Mr. Capek expressed shame about his behavior toward his wife—both the affair and his inability to support her. He subsequently cut off contact with the other woman and attempted to expand his accounting work. The psychiatrist speculated that similar stress was behind his current symptoms.

The psychiatrist communicated regularly with Mr. Capek’s internist. His Lyme disease tests had thus far been negative. When the internist reported this, Mr. Capek became defensive and produced literature on the inaccuracy of Lyme disease testing. Eventually, the internist and the psychiatrist agreed on a conservative treatment approach with a neutral stance regarding the disease’s validity.

On examination, Mr. Capek was a healthy, well-developed adult male. He was anxious and spoke quietly with his eyes closed. He frequently lost his train of thought, but with encouragement and patience, he could give a detailed history consistent with the psychiatrist’s account. Physical examination findings were unremarkable, and a standard laboratory screen was normal except for a slightly low hemoglobin value. The medical team chose to defer further Lyme testing, given the patient’s many past negative tests. However, on hearing about the low hemoglobin, Mr. Capek became alarmed, dismissed reassurances, and insisted that the team investigate this further.
diagnosis:
1. Illness anxiety disorder, care-seeking type
2. Panic disorder
model_thoughts:
**My Diagnostic Formulation for Oscar Capek (43yo Male)**

1.  Somatic Symptom Disorder - F45.1
2.  Panic Disorder - F41.0
3.  Illness Anxiety Disorder - F45.21
4.  Major Depressive Disorder - F32.9
5.  Delusional Disorder - F22

2. Panic Disorder - F41.0
3. Illness Anxiety Disorder - F45.21
4. Major Depressive Disorder - F32.9
5. Delusional Disorder - F22

vignette:
Paulina Delcampo, a 32-year-old single woman with epilepsy that was first diagnosed during adolescence, was admitted to an academic medical center after her family found her convulsing in her bedroom. Before she was taken to the emergency room (ER), emergency medical services administered several doses of lorazepam, with no change in her condition. On arrival at the ER, a loading dose of fosphenytoin was administered to her; it stopped the convulsive activity. Blood tests obtained in the ER revealed therapeutic levels of her usual antiepileptics and no evidence of any infection or metabolic disturbance. Urine toxicology screens were negative for the use of illicit substances. Ms. Delcampo was admitted to the neurology service for further monitoring.

During her admission, a routine electroencephalogram (EEG) was ordered. Shortly after the study began, Ms. Delcampo began convulsing; this prompted administration of intravenous (IV) lorazepam. When the EEG was reviewed, no epileptiform activity was identified. Ms. Delcampo was placed on video-EEG (vEEG) monitoring, and her antiepileptics were tapered and discontinued. In the course of her monitoring, Ms. Delcampo had several episodes of convulsive motor activity; however, none was associated with epileptiform activity on the EEG. Psychiatric consultation was requested.

On interview, Ms. Delcampo denied prior psychiatric evaluations, diagnoses, or treatments. She denied having depressed mood or any disturbance of sleep, energy, concentration, or appetite. She reported no thoughts of harming herself or others. She endorsed no signs or symptoms consistent with mania or psychosis. There was no family history of psychiatric illness or substance abuse. Her examination revealed a well-groomed woman, sitting on her hospital bed with EEG leads in place. She was pleasant and engaged, and she made good eye contact. Cognitive testing revealed no deficits.

Ms. Delcampo noted that she had recently moved to the state to begin graduate school; she was excited about starting her studies and “finally getting my career on track.” She denied any recent specific psychosocial stressors other than her move and said, “My life is finally where I want it to be.” She was future oriented and concerned about the impact that her seizures might have on her long-term health. She was worried that a protracted hospitalization might cause her to miss the first day of classes (only a week away from the time of the interview). Moreover, she was quite concerned about the costs of her hospitalization because her health insurance coverage did not begin until the school semester commenced and the payment for extended benefits coverage from her previous employer would have a significant impact on her budget.

When the findings of the vEEG study were discussed with Ms. Delcampo, she quickly became quite irritable, asking, “So, everyone thinks I’m just making this up?” She was not calmed by her treaters’ attempts to clarify that they did not believe her to be faking her symptoms or by their reassurance that her symptoms might be helped by structured therapy. Ms. Delcampo pulled her EEG leads from her scalp, dressed herself, and left the hospital against medical advice.
diagnosis: Functional neurological symptom disorder (conversion disorder) with attacks or seizures, persistent
model_thoughts:
**Here's how I'm thinking about this patient:**

Okay, so we've got Paulina Delcampo, a 32-year-old woman presenting with what looks like seizures. The key finding here is the vEEG, which confirms non-epileptic seizures. This is the diagnostic pivot, clearly pointing towards Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder, specifically with attacks or seizures (F44.5). It's a textbook presentation for that.

Now, it's not just about the seizures. She's also showing a lot of anxiety and concern about her health, which leads me to strongly consider Somatic Symptom Disorder (F45.1) as a comorbidity. It’s hard to ignore that distress, even though the primary focus is on the seizures.

The move and the stress about grad school are significant, even if she denies it.  That makes Adjustment Disorder with anxiety (F43.22) a strong contender as a contributing factor. The timing is just too perfect.

Factitious Disorder (F68.10) is always on my radar with NES, especially when there's an unusual response to treatment or a concerning history, like this recent AMA discharge. I need to keep it in the back of my mind. It's a differential diagnosis, not the primary one.

Finally, the fact that she has a history of “epilepsy,” is taking medication for it, and had a positive initial response to medication has me thinking about Psychological Factors Affecting Other Medical Conditions (F54). It's plausible that she truly has epilepsy *and* NES, or that the stress of the situation is affecting her epilepsy. This is a subtle but important piece.
model_diagnosis:
1. Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder (Conversion Disorder) - F44.5
2. Somatic Symptom Disorder - F45.1
3. Adjustment Disorder with anxiety - F43.22
4. Psychological factors affecting other medical conditions - F54
5. Factitious disorder imposed on self - F68.10

vignette:
A hospital-based psychiatric consultation-liaison service was called to assess possible depression in Rebecca Ehrlich, a 24-year-old woman who had been hospitalized 2 days earlier for severe abdominal pain. She had been admitted through the emergency room for the latest flare-up of her underlying Crohn’s disease. The consultation was called after the nurses became concerned that she was sad and lonely and was having a difficult time adjusting to her medical condition.

Ms. Ehrlich was interviewed by the medical student on the psychiatry service. The patient indicated that the pain was excruciating and that she was neither sad nor lonely but was simply visiting from out of town, so no one knew she was even in the hospital. She told the medical student that her only previous therapy had been in college, when she went to student health services to get help for anxiety about test taking and her career choice. She had successfully completed a short course of cognitive-behavioral therapy, and the anxiety had not reappeared. She denied any other psychiatric history and had never taken psychiatric medication. In college, she studied psychology and worked part-time as a hospital orderly. Ms. Ehrlich had considered a career in medicine or nursing and asked the student how he had decided to go to medical school.

Ms. Ehrlich reported that she had previously worked regularly and had “quite a few friends,” but that the recurrent abdominal pain had wrecked her social life and her job prospects. She had lost a job the year before because of absenteeism and had missed several job interviews due to her Crohn’s flares. She had dated as a teenager but had been in no relationships since starting college. These things “were not the end of the world, but how would you feel?” As a member of an online bowel disorders support group, Ms. Ehrlich e-mailed other members on a daily basis. She added that the only person in the family who “got” her was an aunt who also had Crohn’s disease.

The primary medical team was having difficulty obtaining collateral information from previous physicians, but the medical student was able to contact Ms. Ehrlich’s mother. She did not know the exact names or phone numbers of her daughter’s medical providers but did recall some of the hospitals and could recall, approximately, some of the physicians’ names. She added that her daughter had not wanted her to be involved in her care and had not told her she was out of town, much less that she was in the hospital. She did say that the Crohn’s disease had been diagnosed 2 years earlier, during her daughter’s last semester of college. The mother estimated that Ms. Ehrlich had been hospitalized at least six times, in contrast with the daughter’s report of two earlier hospitalizations. Neither the gastrointestinal (GI) team nor the medical student was able to locate Ms. Ehrlich’s primary gastroenterologist, whose name the patient could spell only phonetically.

On examination, Ms. Ehrlich was cooperative and conversant, and appeared comfortable. Her speech was fluent. She appeared calm and unworried about her upcoming procedures. Her thought process was linear. She denied paranoia, hallucinations, or suicidality. Attention and both recent and remote memory were intact. She acknowledged that it had been difficult living with Crohn’s disease, but she was optimistic that her symptoms would improve. She denied depressive symptoms. She looked sad at the beginning of the interview, but she appeared more engaged and euthymic the more she talked. She could not explain why the team was unable to locate her doctor and became irritated when the medical student pressed more specifically to elicit further details about her prior care. She was taken to have an endoscopy and a colonoscopy at the end of the interview.

Ms. Ehrlich’s endoscopy and colonoscopy results were normal. That evening, the medical student from psychiatry sat in with the GI team as they reviewed the normal results with the patient. She said she was relieved there was no longer anything seriously wrong with her. The GI team told her that she could be discharged the next morning and that she should have her internist call them. She readily agreed.

After the GI team left, Ms. Ehrlich told the student that she was “feeling better already.” She quickly removed her own intravenous line and started to get dressed. The student went to get the primary GI team. When they returned, the patient was gone.

The medical student spent much of the next day calling hospitals and physicians that met descriptions provided by the patient and her mother. That afternoon, one of the physicians called back and indicated that he had treated Ms. Ehrlich 6 months earlier at a hospital near her mother’s home. That admission was strikingly similar: after a short hospitalization, she quickly fled from the hospital after a normal colonoscopy.
diagnosis: Factitious disorder, recurrent episodes
model_thoughts:
**Here's how I'm approaching this, step-by-step:**

First, I need to understand the goal: diagnose a patient based on this vignette using the DSM-5-TR, following a strict rubric. It's a structured list, no reasoning. I'm internalizing all the diagnostic thinking. Level 5 data extraction and reasoning are expected, but the output is just the list. Okay.

I'm starting by extracting and organizing the key data. This Rebecca Ehrlich, 24, hospitalized with abdominal pain, which seems to be related to Crohn's flare. The nurses are concerned about depression, but she denies it. She claims significant social/occupational impairment, a psychology background, and a past history of CBT for test anxiety. There are inconsistencies right off the bat: her mother's report clashes with hers regarding hospitalizations. Also, she appears too calm and unworried, even despite "excruciating" pain. Endoscopy and Colonoscopy are normal. And then she elopes after the normal results, suggesting deception. And now I'm connecting the dots: She is visiting from "out of town," the lack of contact with her mother, and the lack of a primary GI doctor who is traceable, and the pattern of hospital visits.

The core issue is deception—falsification of symptoms (the abdominal pain, which has now been medically discounted) and concealment (vague doctor names, eloping). So, I'm thinking about Factitious Disorder Imposed on Self. This fits: deception, presentation of illness, absence of obvious external reward (like seeking drugs). It's not psychosis. It's not Malingering, because she doesn't appear to be gaining anything tangible from the hospitalizations. Her primary driver seems to be engagement with medical care, or the "sick role." It's not Somatic Symptom Disorder, because of the deception element. And BPD is a strong possibility given the unstable relationships, identity issues, and self-damaging behavior (hospitalization). ASPD is possible, but the motivation seems to be more about the sick role than manipulation for profit. Depression—the nurses' initial concern— is a strong differential.

Now, let's rank the differential. Factitious Disorder is the leading candidate. Somatic Symptom Disorder is next. It's important to keep that differential open, as it's the closest explanation if the deception wasn't so clear. And then Borderline Personality Disorder and Illness Anxiety Disorder. Let's see. The vignette hints at this. Social Anxiety, maybe, due to test anxiety, but it's not the primary.

Okay, refining the list: Factitious Disorder, Somatic Symptom Disorder, Borderline Personality Disorder, Social Anxiety, and Generalized Anxiety Disorder. But the anxiety diagnosis is "history of". Maybe I need to look at the history again. She had anxiety about test-taking, but "it didn't reappear." Let's rule out current anxiety. Antisocial Personality Disorder might fit better because of deceitfulness, irritability, and irresponsibility. Now, let's choose the clinically defensible list:

*   Factitious Disorder (definitive).
*   Somatic Symptom Disorder (main differential).
*   Borderline Personality Disorder (the underlying personality structure).
*   Antisocial Personality Disorder (the deceptive/violation context).
*   Other Specified Personality Disorder (mixed features).

Okay, ICD-10 codes. We're looking at: F68.10 for Factitious Disorder, F45.1 for Somatic Symptom Disorder, F60.3 for Borderline, F60.2 for Antisocial, and F32.9 for MDD unspecified, or F43.2 for Adjustment Disorder. I'm now realizing that the prompt requests DSM-5-TR psychiatric diagnoses with ICD-10 F-codes. So let's re-evaluate based on the instructions. Okay, so I should prioritize F-code disorders in the list.

Okay, let me re-evaluate, considering depression. Nurses thought she was depressed. She denied it, but affect was initially sad. It belongs in the differential, likely as Adjustment Disorder or MDD to be ruled out. Malingering has to be taken out. It's a Z-code, and the instructions are strict: "Do not include non-psychiatric diagnoses that do not use F-codes."

The "top 5" will include what mimics or co-occurs or was suspected.

*   Factitious disorder imposed on self: F68.10.
*   Somatic symptom disorder: F45.1.
*   Borderline personality disorder: F60.3.
*   Adjustment disorder with depressed mood: F43.21.
*   Antisocial personality disorder: F60.2.

This
model_diagnosis:
1. Factitious disorder imposed on self - ICD-10 F68.10
2. Somatic symptom disorder - ICD-10 F45.1
3. Borderline personality disorder - ICD-10 F60.3
4. Antisocial personality disorder - ICD-10 F60.2
5. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood - ICD-10 F43.21

vignette:
Thomas, an 8-year-old boy with a mild to moderate intellectual developmental disorder, was brought into the emergency room (ER) by his parents after his abdominal pain of the past several weeks had worsened over the prior 24 hours. His parents reported that he had developed constipation, with only one bowel movement in the past week, and that he had vomited earlier in the day. Teachers at his special education classroom for children with intellectual developmental disorders had written a report earlier in the week indicating that Thomas had been having difficulties since soon after transferring from a similar school in a different state about 4 months earlier. The teachers and parents agreed that Thomas often looked distressed, rocking, crying, and clutching his stomach.

One week earlier, a pediatrician had diagnosed an acute exacerbation of chronic constipation. Use of a recommended over-the-counter laxative was not helpful, and Thomas began to complain of nighttime pain. The discomfort led to a diminished interest in his favorite hobbies, which were video games and sports. Instead, he tended to stay in his room, playing with army men figurines that he had inherited from his grandfather’s collection. Aside from episodes of irritability and tearfulness, he was generally doing well in school, both in the classroom and on the playground. When not complaining of stomachaches, Thomas ate well and maintained his position at about the 40th percentile for height and weight on the growth curve.

Thomas’s past medical history was significant for constipation and stomachaches, as well as for intermittent headaches. All of these symptoms had worsened several months earlier, after the family moved from a house in semirural Florida into an old walk-up apartment in a large urban city in a different state. He shared a room with his younger brother (age 6 years), the product of a normal, unexpected pregnancy, who was enrolled in a regular education class at the local public school. Thomas said his brother was his “best friend.” Thomas was adopted at birth, and nothing was known of his biological parents except that they were teenagers unable to care for the child.

On medical examination in the ER, Thomas was a well-groomed boy sitting on his mother’s lap. He was crying and irritable and refused to speak to the examiner. Instead, he would repeat to his parents that his stomach hurt. On physical examination, he was afebrile and had stable vital signs. His physical examination was remarkable only for general abdominal tenderness, although he was difficult to assess because he cried uncontrollably through most of the exam.

An abdominal X ray revealed multiple small metallic particles throughout the gastrointestinal tract, initially suspected to be ingested high-lead paint flakes, as well as three 2-centimeter-long metallic objects in his stomach. A blood lead level was 20 μg/dL (whereas normal level for children is < 5 μg/dL). More specific questioning revealed that Thomas, being constipated, often spent long stretches on the toilet by himself. His parents added that although the bathroom was in the process of being renovated, its paint was old and peeling. Consultants decided that the larger foreign bodies in the stomach might not safely pass and could be accounting for the constipation. Endoscopy successfully extricated three antique toy soldiers from Thomas’s stomach.
diagnosis:
1. Pica
2. Intellectual developmental disorder, mild to moderate
model_thoughts:
**My Thought Process on Diagnosing Thomas**

Okay, here's how I'm thinking about this case, step-by-step. First, I have to remember my role as a psychiatrist using the DSM-5-TR, and my goal is to come up with the most likely diagnoses based on the provided information, using my rubric.

I started by carefully reviewing the vignette – Thomas, an 8-year-old with mild to moderate IDD, is presenting with worsening abdominal pain, constipation, and vomiting. There's a history of a recent move, school difficulties, and a pediatrician diagnosed constipation but meds didn't help. The important things that caught my attention were that he was eating paint and toy soldiers, which is a big red flag. Also, his level of functioning seems to have dropped; the move and recent events are major stressors. The results also showed high lead levels in his blood and the presence of these foreign objects in the x-ray and endoscopy.

Next, I delved into the specifics. Thomas’s ingestion of non-nutritive substances, lead poisoning and the impaction needed to be prioritized. It became pretty clear that Pica was the core problem here. Since the IDD diagnosis was pre-existing, it had to be a part of the diagnostic impression, I didn't want to overstate the IDD, and it was a "mild-to-moderate" condition that had to be addressed. Furthermore, these behaviors were not normal at his age and development and needed to be addressed immediately.

The vignette's description suggests that these symptoms are likely a result of the ingestion of the toxic substances. The move and the stress were also key factors. So, I thought about Adjustment Disorder, but felt it was secondary to the medical conditions. The elevated lead levels and the medical symptoms drove this process, so I needed to reflect this in the diagnoses. The behavioral changes (irritability, withdrawal) are direct consequences of lead poisoning, not an independent psychological condition, making “Personality Change due to another medical condition” and “Depressive Disorder due to another medical condition” more fitting.

I also considered other possibilities. Rule-outs included ARFID, rumination, major depressive disorder and Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). ASD was a big consideration due to the repetitive behaviors, but he has a friend and social history, making ASD less likely. There wasn't enough to confirm an ASD diagnosis, but it remains a strong differential.

Next, I focused on building the list. Pica was the obvious first choice, and it had to be F50.8, the standard code for the disorder. Then came the pre-existing Intellectual Developmental Disorder (F71 for moderate, as that level of support seems indicated from the vignette), which needed to be addressed as this would influence his reactions to the environment. The adjustment to the move and school would have to be captured as “Adjustment Disorder” (F43.23), which made sense given the timeline. Next, I included “Personality change due to another medical condition” (F07.0) to capture the irritability and other behaviors caused by lead exposure. Finally, I went with “Psychological factors affecting other medical conditions (F54)”, because the stress of the move and school definitely had a role.

I debated between several alternate options, and after a lot of thought and reviewing the evidence, I went with the list that best captured the patient's presentation and medical context. I made sure to check the ICD-10 codes against the DSM-5-TR and the format.

In the end, this is my final list:

1.  Pica - F50.8
2.  Intellectual developmental disorder, moderate - F71
3.  Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood - F43.23
4.  Personality change due to another medical condition - F07.0
5.  Psychological factors affecting other medical conditions - F54
model_diagnosis:
1. Pica - F50.8
2. Intellectual developmental disorder, moderate - F71
3. Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood - F43.23
4. Personality change due to another medical condition - F07.0
5. Psychological factors affecting other medical conditions - F54

vignette:
Uma, an 11-year-old girl in a gifted and talented school, was referred to an eating disorder specialist by a child psychiatrist who was concerned that Uma had drifted below the 10th percentile for weight. The psychiatrist had been treating Uma for perfectionistic traits that caused her significant anxiety. Their sessions focused on anxiety, not on eating behavior.

Uma’s eating difficulties started at age 9, when she began refusing to eat and reporting a fear that she would vomit. At that time, her parents sought treatment from a pediatrician, who continued to evaluate her yearly, explaining that it was normal for children to go through phases. At age 9, Uma was above the 25th percentile for both height and weight (52 inches, 58 pounds), but by age 11, she had essentially stopped growing and had dropped to the 5th percentile on her growth curves (52.5 inches, 55 pounds).

The only child of two professional parents who had divorced 5 years earlier, Uma lived with her mother on weekdays and with her nearby father on weekends. Her medical history was significant for her premature birth at 34 weeks’ gestation. She was slow to achieve her initial milestones but by age 2 was developmentally normal. Yearly physical examinations had been unremarkable with the exception of the recent decline of her growth trajectory. Uma had always been petite, but her height and weight had never fallen below the 25th percentile for stature and weight for age on the growth chart. Uma was a talented student who was well liked by her teachers. She had never had more than a few friends, but recently she had stopped socializing entirely and had been coming directly home after school, reporting that her stomach felt calmer when she was in her own home.

For the prior 2 years, Uma had eaten only very small amounts of food over very long durations of time. Her parents had tried to pique her interest by experimenting with foods from different cultures and of different colors and textures. None of this seemed effective in improving her appetite. They also tried to let her pick restaurants to try, but Uma had gradually refused to eat outside of either parent’s home. Both parents reported a similar mealtime pattern: Uma would agree to sit at the table but then spent her time rearranging food on her plate, cutting food items into small pieces, and crying if urged to eat another bite.

When asked more about her fear of vomiting, Uma remembered one incident, at age 4, when she ate soup and her stomach became upset and then she subsequently vomited. More recently, Uma had developed fear of eating in public and ate no food during the school day. She denied any concerns about her appearance and said that she had first become aware of her low weight at her most recent visit to the pediatrician. When educated about the dangers of low body weight, Uma became tearful and expressed a clear desire to gain weight.
diagnosis: Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder
model_thoughts:
**My Diagnostic Thought Process: A Deep Dive into Uma's Case**

Okay, here's how I approached this. First, I locked in my role and the task. Expert Psychiatrist, diagnosing using DSM-5-TR, level 5 rubric, and a specific format (no reasoning). Right away, I start dissecting the vignette, pulling out every relevant detail. Uma's age, the growth failure, the emetophobia, the eating behaviors, the social impact, the past psychiatric and social history... every piece is a potential puzzle piece. I'm going for that level 5: noticing the subtle cues and complex relationships.

I immediately honed in on the **Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID)**. This just *screams* ARFID – the weight loss, the failure to thrive, the fear of vomiting, and the lack of body image distortion. It's the aversive consequence subtype perfectly. I have to make sure it's the primary, though.

Then, the **Specific Phobia (Emetophobia)** pops up. While ARFID gets priority because it explains the *consequences*, the phobia is the driver. But remember the DSM-5-TR hierarchy. ARFID is *usually* preferred if the eating disturbance is severe, which it is here. I note it as a secondary, or potentially comorbid, diagnosis since the fear is so specific.

Next, the **Social Anxiety Disorder** is screaming from the vignette. The girl is avoiding eating in public, and withdrawing from social situations. With the perfectionistic traits, it really suggests a broader anxiety component. But I have to distinguish *why* she's avoiding. Is it just about the eating, or the scrutiny?

And then, the **Generalized Anxiety Disorder** comes into focus. She's already being treated for something like this! The perfectionism and the stomach aches, the "calmer at home" feeling – textbook GAD.

I had to rule out **Anorexia Nervosa** because she denies appearance concerns and wants to gain weight. It's important to differentiate from what may be a similar presentation. That needs to be made explicit, and it's quickly ruled out.

**Separation Anxiety Disorder** is also on the list, given the age, the divorce, and the "calm at home" statement. This is a possibility. Maybe some Agoraphobia given she doesn't like to leave the house. But is it driven by the food phobia? Hard to say, I'd need more data.

I made sure to exclude anything else that might be in the diagnostic mix. The eating behaviors had to be assessed. *Is the cause in this situation clear?*

Finally, I checked my output. I made sure to prioritize the most important diagnoses, ARFID first, the others as secondary considerations, and listed the F-codes. I confirmed that I had a good representation of this patient in a final output.
model_diagnosis:
1. Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder - ICD-10 F50.82
2. Social anxiety disorder - ICD-10 F40.10
3. Generalized anxiety disorder - ICD-10 F41.1
4. Specific phobia (fear of vomiting) - ICD-10 F40.298
5. Separation anxiety disorder - ICD-10 F93.0

vignette:
Wanda Hoffman was a 24-year-old woman who was referred to a psychiatrist by her internist. She said she felt sad, worthless, and lonely. She reported that she needed to improve her diet and exercise but felt out of control. She added that she had gone to her internist several times in recent months for stomachaches, and he finally insisted that she see a psychiatrist.

Ms. Hoffman had been living alone since her college graduation 2 years earlier. She had recently been promoted in her job as an accountant, and said that she enjoyed her work. She mentioned having some friends from high school and being interested in dating, but she felt too tired and sad to do much besides meet up for a quick dinner after work. She was unable to exercise because of low energy, slept poorly, and frequently had stomachaches. These symptoms and the resulting social dysfunction had caused her to feel increasingly isolated, lonely, and sad. She often found herself feeling worthless and wondering how she was going to get through the week, but she denied suicidal intent or plan.

She said she had accepted the psychiatric referral so that she could get an antidepressant medication, but “it had to be one that didn’t cause weight gain. Hopefully, I could get one that would cause weight loss, instead.” Ms. Hoffman added that she couldn’t get back to her ideal weight despite lots of effort. When asked about the effort, Ms. Hoffman grew quiet but did eventually answer: “I wasn’t going to talk about this, but I’m a ‘failed anorexic.’ I can diet for about half a day, but by dinner, I’m starving, so I eat everything I can find, and then I throw up. It’s mortifying.”

Ms. Hoffman reported that she had started dieting at about age 13; she noted that, in retrospect, she was “being ridiculous,” and that her weight had been fine. She said her downfall really began when she started “stress eating” in college. When she realized she had gained 10 or 15 pounds, she began to routinely skip breakfast. She often skipped lunch as well, but then, famished, she would overeat in the late afternoon and evening.

By the end of her sophomore year, Ms. Hoffman had started inducing vomiting, a practice she learned about in a magazine. She had developed her current eating pattern during her junior year and continued it after graduation: no breakfast; a “light” lunch; an “average” dinner, often with friends; and then she’d rush back to her apartment for a second dinner and a pint or two of ice cream, followed by self-induced vomiting.
diagnosis:
1. Bulimia nervosa
2. Major depressive disorder
model_thoughts:
**Here's how I'm thinking about this diagnosis, step by step:**

Okay, so I'm an expert psychiatrist and I'm being asked to diagnose this patient, Wanda, based on the DSM-5-TR. I need to give the top 5 diagnoses in a structured list with ICD-10 codes, with Bulimia Nervosa as the primary.

1.  **First, I need to understand the request:** I'm in the role of an expert, the task is a diagnosis, and the output needs to be a specific format. I need to be focused on the relevant parts of the clinical presentation. Wanda is a 24-year-old female.

2.  **Next, I'll extract and organize the data:** I'm pulling out the key information: her complaints of sadness, worthlessness, loneliness, and feeling out of control regarding her diet and exercise. I'm noting the timeline: four years of vomiting, with the current pattern of binging, purging, and restriction established for the last two years. She has a history of dieting starting at age 13 and weight gain in college. There's also the mental status cues, like being "mortified" by her behavior. No suicidal thoughts or plans. I'm also looking for substance and medical history - referred by an internist for stomachaches, likely due to purging.

3.  **Now, it's time for diagnostic reasoning and differential diagnosis:** This is where I start piecing things together.

    *   **Primary Symptom Cluster - Eating Disorders:** I'm looking at *Bulimia Nervosa* first. It fits the recurrent binge eating, the inappropriate compensatory behavior (vomiting), the frequency and duration criteria (at least once a week for 3 months), and her self-evaluation being overly influenced by her body shape and weight. I'm ruling out *Anorexia Nervosa* because she has an apparent history of weight gain and does not currently maintain a low body weight. I'm also ruling out *Binge-Eating Disorder* because of the purging behavior. *Bulimia Nervosa* is the strongest fit for the primary diagnosis.

    *   **Secondary Symptom Cluster - Mood/Depression:** *Major Depressive Disorder (MDD)* seems likely. She's got sadness, worthlessness, fatigue/low energy, poor sleep, and anhedonia (loss of interest) from the case.  I'm weighing the timeline, as these symptoms seem chronic or worsened by the eating disorder. Even though these symptoms are common with eating disorders, the severity warrants a separate diagnosis. I'll need to consider this.  If these mood symptoms are purely related to the eating disorder, I might hesitate. I'll consider *Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)* if the symptoms are long-standing. I'll consider *Unspecified Depressive Disorder* if the criteria for MDD aren't fully met. I might also need to decide how the mood symptoms relate to the bulimia.

    *   **Secondary Symptom Cluster - Body Image/Obsessive traits:** *Body Dysmorphic Disorder* can usually be excluded if the weight/shape concern is explained by an eating disorder. Here, it fits with *Bulimia*, so it can be excluded.

    *   **Secondary Symptom Cluster - Personality:** I'm thinking about *Borderline Personality Disorder*, with the "out of control" feelings and a history with eating disorders. I'll need to know if there's any evidence of self-harm, unstable relationships, or fear of abandonment. There's nothing in this case to support this. I also need to consider *Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder*, with the perfectionism. I think her rigidity of dieting and focus might be related to this, but the bingeing is impulsive so it would not be a perfect fit.

    *   **Refining the Top 5 List:** I'm considering all these possibilities and creating the final list. I am also checking my choices against the DSM-5.

        1.  **Bulimia Nervosa (F50.2):** This is the main diagnosis, the eating disorder fits the bill.
        2.  **Major Depressive Disorder, Single Episode, Moderate (F32.1):** I believe this is a comorbidity for many of the symptoms.
        3.  **Generalized Anxiety Disorder (F41.1) / Unspecified Anxiety Disorder (F41.9):** I have high-level concern for anxiety due to stress, and the fact that she has a pattern. I need to use caution with what symptoms exist.  Unspecified anxiety is often a better fit if the specific criteria aren't met.
        4.  **Unspecified Depressive Disorder (F32.A) or Persistent Depressive Disorder (F34
model_diagnosis:
1. Bulimia Nervosa - F50.2
2. Major Depressive Disorder, Single episode, moderate - F32.1
3. Generalized Anxiety Disorder - F41.1
4. Insomnia Disorder - F51.01
5. Unspecified Personality Disorder - F60.9

vignette:
Yasmine Isherwood, a 55-year-old married woman, had been in psychiatric treatment for 6 months for an episode of major depressive disorder. She had responded well to a combination of psychotherapy and medications (fluoxetine and bupropion), but she began to complain of weight gain. She was at her “highest weight ever,” which was 140 pounds (her height was 5 feet 5 inches, so her BMI was 23.3).

The psychiatrist embarked on a clarification of Ms. Isherwood’s eating history, which was marked by recurrent, distressing episodes of uncontrollable eating of large amounts of food. The overeating was not new but seemed to have worsened while she was taking antidepressants. She reported that she often worked late in her job as marketing director for a large software company, and that the eating episodes often occurred on one of 2 days per week that she happened to get home before her husband, a cardiologist at a local hospital. These “eating jags” were notable for a sense that she was out of control. She ate rapidly and alone, until uncomfortably full. She would then feel depressed, tired, and disgusted with herself. She usually binged on healthy food but also had “sugar binges” where she ate primarily sweets, especially ice cream and candy. She denied current or past self-induced vomiting, fasting, or misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or weight-loss agents. She reported exercising for an hour almost every day but denied being “addicted” to it. She did report that in her late 20s, she had become a competitive runner. At that time, she ran an average of about 35 miles per week, despite a lingering foot injury that eventually forced her to shift to swimming, biking, and the elliptical machine.

Ms. Isherwood stated that she had binged on food “for as long as I can remember.” She was “chunky” as a child but stayed at a normal weight throughout high school (120–125 pounds) because she was so active. She denied a history of anorexia nervosa. At age 28, when she was competitively running, she reached her lowest adult weight of 113 pounds. At that point, she felt “vital, healthy, and in control.”

In her mid-30s, she had a major depressive episode that lasted 2 years. She had a severely depressed mood, did not talk, “closed down,” stayed in bed, was very fatigued, slept more than usual, and was unable to function. This was one of the few times in her life that the binge eating stopped and she lost weight. She denied a history of hypomanic or manic episodes. Although she lived with frequent sadness, she denied other serious depressive episodes until the past year. She denied a history of suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, and any significant use of alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances.

The evaluation revealed a well-nourished, well-developed female who was coherent and cooperative. Her speech was fluent and not pressured. She had a mildly depressed mood but had a reactive affect with appropriate smiles. She denied guilt, suicidality, and hopelessness. She said her energy was normal except for post-binge fatigue. She denied psychosis and confusion. Her cognition was normal. Her medical history was unremarkable, and physical examination and basic laboratory test results provided by her internist were within normal limits.
diagnosis:
1. Binge-eating disorder, mild
2. Major depressive disorder, recurrent, in remission
model_thoughts:
**Final Diagnostic Impressions for Yasmine Isherwood**

Okay, here's the breakdown of what I'm thinking, based on this case. First off, I'm zeroing in on **Binge-Eating Disorder (F50.81)** as the primary issue. The clinical presentation is pretty clear-cut: recurrent episodes of eating large amounts, a sense of loss of control, distress afterward, and no evidence of purging or other compensatory behaviors beyond her regular exercise routine. Her weight gain also aligns with this, making the BED the most likely issue.

Second, given her history and current status, **Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent, In Partial Remission (F33.41)** is definitely a factor. She had a previous major episode, responded well to treatment, but still has lingering symptoms. This isn't the primary driver currently, as the eating seems to be the focus of the distress, so it sits as a comorbidity.

Now, as an ED specialist, I must consider a few *differential* diagnoses. The biggest one is **Bulimia Nervosa (F50.2)**. Her history of exercise and the way the exercise is described raise a possible concern. However, I am interpreting the exercise as a lifestyle habit (given her history as a runner), and not as a direct attempt to offset the binge eating. If I were uncertain, I might put Bulimia higher.

Following that, I'm including **Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorder (F50.8)** as a fallback. This captures the possibility that the clinical picture doesn't neatly fit the exact criteria for BED or Bulimia. This is more of a safety net, really.

And finally, given her competitive history, and lack of clarity on the full criteria, I'm also considering **Unspecified Personality Disorder (F60.9)**. The rigid exercise and work habits, along with the "well-nourished" presentation gives me pause, but it doesn't meet the requirements for a full diagnosis.

So, in this order:

1.  Binge-Eating Disorder - F50.81
2.  Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent, In Partial Remission - F33.41
3.  Bulimia Nervosa - F50.2
4.  Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorder - F50.8
5.  Unspecified personality disorder - F60.9
model_diagnosis:
1. Binge-eating disorder - F50.81
2. Major depressive disorder, recurrent, in partial remission - F33.41
3. Bulimia nervosa - F50.2
4. Other specified feeding or eating disorder - F50.8
5. Unspecified personality disorder - F60.9

vignette:
Zack was an 8-year-old boy brought to the outpatient child psychiatry clinic by his mother because of increasing tantrums and somatic complaints without an apparent cause. The mother reported that the symptoms appeared related to the nights that he spent with his aunt, another single mom with a boy similar in age to Zack. He had been close to this aunt since birth but had only recently begun to spend every Friday night with her when the mother took on a night shift at work.

For 2 months prior to the consultation, Zack would report nausea and headaches on Fridays and complain that his aunt’s house was “creepy.” He continued to visit, with reluctance, although he did once call his mother at work demanding that she pick him up, saying, “Other kids live in their own home every day of the week.”

In recent weeks, Zack screamed and hid when it came time to go to his aunt’s home. His mother became concerned that something could have “happened” to Zack during a visit. The mother struggled to reconcile this with the fact that Zack had no objections to seeing the aunt and cousin anywhere else, and he had no objection to the cousin sleeping at their home. Her sister had always been “a good mom” and was always home during the sleepovers. She did have a boyfriend, but Zack seemed to like him. In fact, Zack seemed especially excited to go to the park or ball games with his cousin and the boyfriend.

Zack had never previously had particularly significant separation, behavioral, or emotional issues. He achieved all developmental milestones on time. He had never seen a doctor aside from routine visits and one bad cold when he was age 3. Zack had yet to achieve consistent overnight continence, however, and did wet the bed approximately twice weekly. He had no daytime voiding symptoms or constipation. The pediatrician had told them that this was “normal” at Zack’s age. The mother had never made a big deal about the bed-wetting, and Zack had never expressed significant distress about it.

Family history was negative for all psychiatric illness on the mother’s side, and the mother said her own developmental landmarks were normal as far as she had been told. The mother knew little about Zack’s father’s developmental or family history, and she had not seen him since before Zack was born.

On mental status examination, Zack was cooperative and appeared well nourished and well cared for. He had little difficulty separating from his mother. After an initial period of warming up to the interviewer, his speech was spontaneous with a vocabulary appropriate for his age. He maintained age-appropriate eye contact. His affect was initially mildly anxious, but he rapidly calmed. Anxiety only reappeared upon discussing his sleepovers, when Zack demonstrated some fidgeting, decreased eye contact, and mild irritability directed toward his mother. When asked about the bed-wetting, Zack appeared embarrassed. He said he had wet the bed at his aunt’s house a few times and that both his cousin and his aunt’s boyfriend teased him about it. His aunt had intervened, but he described being “scared” that he would do it again.
diagnosis: Enuresis, nocturnal only
model_thoughts:
**Here's the summary of my thought process:**

Okay, here we go. The user wants a structured list of diagnoses based on this clinical case. The prompt specifies to follow a rubric and to avoid explaining my reasoning, but to act as if I am formulating these thoughts. First, I need to extract all the relevant details from the provided text, which I'll organize: the patient is an 8-year-old boy named Zack, the chief complaint revolves around increasing tantrums and physical symptoms linked to a specific Friday night situation at his aunt's place. The problem began two months ago and is tied to sleepovers at his aunt's, triggered by his mom starting a night shift. I'm noting key symptoms like anticipatory anxiety, reluctance to sleep away from home, and the details surrounding his bed-wetting (enuresis). Next, *Social Anxiety Disorder* comes to mind. The fear of being embarrassed about the bedwetting sounds like it fits here. I'm focusing on the context of social situations, the possibility of negative evaluation, and Zack's avoidance.

Then, *Enuresis*, seems pretty straightforward, as he's over five years old and has been wetting the bed regularly. It is nocturnal, primary enuresis, which I need to code correctly.

I'm also considering the duration of this and noting the DSM-5 guideline of 6 months for anxiety disorders, and whether strict adherence applies here for this expert task. Finally, *Specific Phobia (Situational)* is a thought, but it seems less likely given the social aspects. The fear is rooted in social scrutiny, not the aunt's house itself, which makes it less relevant.

I need to create the hierarchy of diagnosis, based on the provided rubric. I know *Enuresis* is the starting point, as this is a defined physiological/behavioral issue. This seems clear.

Okay, I'm thinking *Adjustment Disorder with Anxiety* fits because the behavioral changes started two months ago, are linked to the stressor and because this is the primary reason for the clinical visit. I'm ruling out other diagnoses, but I'll make sure to note those and I'll keep social and separation anxiety disorders in mind as "rule outs" or differential. The DSM-5 text supports Separation Anxiety Disorder. The prompt and rubric support considering all the possibilities, so I must consider this diagnosis. The DSM-5 states the 6-month time frame often helps rule out transient fears and the symptoms here are only 2 months old. vignette:
Aidan Johns, a 30-year-old graduate student in English, visited a psychiatrist to discuss his difficulty staying asleep. The trouble began 4 months earlier, when he started to wake up at 3:00 every morning, no matter when he went to bed, and then was unable to fall back to sleep. As a result, he felt “out of it” during the day. This led him to feel increasingly worried about how he was going to finish his doctoral dissertation when he was unable to concentrate owing to exhaustion. When his sleep difficulties began, he woke with nothing particular on his mind. As the trouble persisted, he found himself dreading the upcoming day and wondering how he would teach his classes or focus on his writing if he was getting only a few hours of sleep. Some mornings he lay awake in the dark next to his fiancée, who was sleeping soundly. On other mornings he would cut his losses, rise from bed, and go very early to his office on campus.

After a month of interrupted sleep, Mr. Johns visited a physician’s assistant at the university’s student health services, where he customarily got his medical care. (He suffered from asthma, for which he occasionally took inhaled β2-adrenergic receptor agonists, and a year earlier he had had mononucleosis.) The physician’s assistant prescribed a sedative-hypnotic, which did not help. “Falling asleep was never the problem,” Mr. Johns explained. Meanwhile, he heeded some of the advice he read online. Although he felt reliant on coffee during the day, he never drank it after 2:00 p.m. An avid tennis player, he restricted his court time to the early morning. He did have a glass or two of wine every night at dinner with his fiancée, however. “By dinnertime I start to worry about whether I’ll be able to sleep,” he said, “and, to be honest, the wine helps.”

The patient, a slender and fit-appearing young man looking very much the part of the young academic in a tweed jacket and tortoise-rimmed glasses, was pleasant and open in his storytelling. Mr. Johns did not appear tired but told the evaluating psychiatrist, “I made a point to see you in the morning, before I hit the wall.” He did not look sad or on edge and was not sure if he had ever felt depressed. But he was certain of the nagging, low-level anxiety that was currently oppressing him. “This sleep problem has taken over,” he explained. “I’m stressed about my work, and my fiancée and I have been arguing. But it’s all because I’m so tired.”

Although this was his first visit to a psychiatrist, Mr. Johns spoke of a fulfilling 3-year psychodynamic psychotherapy with a social worker while in college. “I was just looking to understand myself better,” he explained, adding with a chuckle that as the son of a child psychiatrist, he was accustomed to people assuming he was “crazy.” He recalled always being an “easy sleeper” prior to his recent difficulties; as a child he was the first to fall asleep at slumber parties, and as an adult he inspired the envy of his fiancée for the ease with which he could doze off on an airplane.
diagnosis: Insomnia disorder
model_thoughts:
**Expert Diagnostic Thought Process: A Case of Aidan Johns**

Alright, let's break this down. First, I'm taking the prompt as an expert psychiatrist, tasked with diagnosing a clinical vignette. The instructions are clear: DSM-5-TR, ACGME Level 5 data extraction and diagnostic reasoning, and a strict F-code list with no justification. I'm focusing on the data, thinking like a psychiatrist.

I've got the data on Aidan Johns - 30, English grad student, chronic early morning awakening. The duration of 4 months immediately triggers my thinking about diagnostic criteria. I’m zeroing in on the details: the 3 AM wakening, the daytime fatigue, and the anxiety about his work and dissertation. It's a classic presentation.

Right off the bat, "Insomnia Disorder" jumps to mind. But I need to rule out other causes. Aidan denies depression, and he doesn’t *look* depressed, which makes me lean away from a depressive disorder. Generalized Anxiety Disorder doesn't quite fit either, as the anxiety is *focused* specifically on sleep.

His alcohol use warrants a closer look. The "wine helps" comment is crucial. Alcohol's biphasic effects are well-known - it might induce sleep at first, but it can absolutely cause early morning awakening and sleep fragmentation. I'm noting the potential for alcohol-induced sleep disorder, or at least a contributing role. The stimulant effect of the asthma inhaler is noted, but not the focus given the occasional use.

The fact that he was an "easy sleeper" previously suggests a change has occurred. This helps in understanding the recent onset of the insomnia. His history of therapy isn't pathological and is helpful to know as the base level. No other major medical concerns.

Okay, let's synthesize. Given the clear insomnia pattern, duration, and impact, "Insomnia Disorder" feels like the primary. The "nagging anxiety" about sleep maintenance cements this thought. The alcohol seems to be a significant contributor. Alcohol-Induced Sleep Disorder could be co-primary if it's causing the sleep disorder, but I'm going to keep it as an additional factor that needs attention, as the insomnia started before regular alcohol usage. Advanced Sleep Phase type is a valid differential. The "unspecified anxiety" is the general stress.

So, here's my top list:
1.  Insomnia Disorder
2.  Alcohol-Induced Sleep Disorder
3.  Unspecified Anxiety Disorder
4.  Adjustment Disorder
5.  Circadian Rhythm Sleep-Wake Disorder

I have to choose five. I am feeling confident with this list.

The codes need to be F-codes and precise.
1. F51.01 (Insomnia Disorder) is perfect.
2. F10.180 (Alcohol use with Sleep Disorder)
3. F43.22 (Adjustment Disorder)
4. F41.9 (Unspecified Anxiety)
5. F51.3 (Circadian Rhythm Sleep-Wake)

Now, I'm checking the final output, and it's concise, exactly as requested. Diagnostic codes. Clean. All F-codes. It's solid.
model_diagnosis:
1. Insomnia Disorder - F51.01
2. Alcohol-Induced Sleep Disorder - F10.180
3. Adjustment Disorder with Anxiety - F43.22
4. Unspecified Anxiety Disorder - F41.9
5. Circadian Rhythm Sleep-Wake Disorder, Advanced Sleep Phase Type - F51.3

vignette:
Bernadette Kleber was a 34-year-old divorced, unemployed white mother of three school-age children. She was living with a new companion. Ms. Kleber presented to a psychiatrist for anxiety and sleepiness.

Ms. Kleber had experienced anxiety much of her life, but she had become much more worried and stressed since the birth of her first child 10 years before. She said she was “okay at home” but anxious in social situations. She avoided having to interact with new people, fearing that she would be embarrassed and judged. For example, she wanted to lose the weight that she had gained since the births of her children (current body mass index [BMI] 27.7) but was afraid of the ridicule that might accompany her efforts at the gym. She had gradually withdrawn from situations in which she might be forced to meet new people, and this made it almost impossible for her to interview for a new job, much less work in one. She had been successfully treated for social anxiety disorder 5 years earlier with psychotherapy, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor [SSRI] antidepressant, and clonazepam 0.25 mg twice daily, but her symptoms had returned over the prior year. She denied increasing the dose of either medication or taking any other medication (prescribed or over the counter) for anxiety. Although excited about her new relationship, she was worried her new girlfriend would leave her if she did not “tune up my act.”

She denied periods of significant depression, although she said she had experienced multiple periods of feeling frustrated with her limited effectiveness. She also denied all manic symptoms.

The psychiatrist then asked Ms. Kleber about her “sleepiness.” She said she slept more than anyone she knew. She said she typically slept at least 9 hours per night but then took two naps for 5 additional hours during the day. She did not recall a problem until the end of high school, when she started falling asleep around 8:00 or 9:00 p.m. and dozing every afternoon. When she tried to go to college, she realized how much more sleep she needed than her friends and eventually dropped out because she could not stay awake in class. Despite the naps, she typically fell asleep when visiting friends or family and when reading or watching TV. She quit driving alone for fear of falling asleep at the wheel. Late afternoon naps were not restorative and had no apparent impact on her falling asleep at night.

Raising a family was difficult, especially because mornings were Ms. Kleber’s worst period. For at least half an hour after waking, she was disoriented and confused, making it difficult to get her children to school. Throughout the day, she said she felt “scattered and inattentive.”

Snoring had appeared 5 years earlier. Her companion was unsure whether Ms. Kleber also had breathing pauses during her sleep. Ms. Kleber denied having ever experienced sleep paralysis or abruptly falling asleep in the middle of a sentence. Although she would fall asleep while socializing, it would generally occur during a lull in the conversation while she was in a quiet spot in the corner of a couch. She denied falling down when she fell asleep. She reported experiencing hypnopompic hallucinations several times per year since she was a teenager.

On examination, Ms. Kleber was an overweight woman who was cooperative and coherent. She was concerned about her anxiety but preoccupied with her sleep problem. She denied depression, suicidality, psychosis, and memory complaints. Her insight and judgment appeared intact.
